informal_statement:
Find $24^{-1} \pmod{11^2}$. That is, find the residue $b$ for which $24b \equiv 1\pmod{11^2}$.

Express your answer as an integer from $0$ to $11^2-1$, inclusive. Show that it is 116.
informal_proof: Since $5 \times 24 = 120 = 121 - 1$, it follows that $-5 \times 24 \equiv 1 \pmod{121}$. Adding 121 to $-5$ to make it positive, we find $(-5 + 121) \times 24 \equiv 116 \times 24 \equiv 1 \pmod{121}$, so it follows that the modular inverse of $24$ is $116$ when taken modulo $121$.
formal_statement:
theorem mathd_numbertheory_233:
  fixes b::int
  assumes "\<forall>b::int. 0\<le>b \<and> b\<le>11^2 \<and> [b * 24 = 1] (mod (11^2))"
  shows "b = 116"
formal_code:
(*
  Authors: Wenda Li
*)

theory mathd_numbertheory_233 
  imports Complex_Main "HOL-Computational_Algebra.Computational_Algebra"
          "HOL-Number_Theory.Number_Theory"
begin

theorem mathd_numbertheory_233:
  fixes b::int
  assumes "0\<le>b"
    and "b<11^2"
    and "[b * 24 = 1] (mod (11^2))"
  shows "b = 116"
  sorry

end
